## üåç Distribution of duckweed species in Florida

In addition to the _Salvina minima_ and _Lemna minor_, several other varieties of duckweed exist across Florida.  You may wish to consider comparing interactions among combinations of interaction of local duckweed as well. 


::: {.panel}
<details>
  <summary>Landoltia</summary>
  Distribution:   [Landoltia on iNaturalist](https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/72211-Landoltia)   (Dotted Duckweed)
  
    [https://plant-directory.ifas.ufl.edu/plant-directory/landoltia-punctata](https://plant-directory.ifas.ufl.edu/plant-directory/landoltia-punctata)

    Species: Landoltia punctata

    Origin: Introduced from Australia and Southeast Asia

    Size: Fronds 1‚Äì3 mm wide, elliptical shape

    Roots: 2‚Äì5 per frond

    Distinctive Features: Lacks red dot on upper frond (unlike Spirodela),  underside has sunken glands, giving a dotted texture

    Habitat: Common in slow-moving waters, ponds, and swamps throughout Florida

    Status: Non-native; likely introduced via aquarium trade 

</details>
:::

::: {.panel}
<details>
<summary>Lemna</summary>
  - Distribution: [Lemna](https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/54519-Lemna)
  
  - Species in Florida: Lemna minor, Lemna valdiviana, and Lemna perpusilla

  - Size: Fronds up to 6 mm long

  - Roots: Single root per frond

  - Distinctive Features: Flat, oval-shaped fronds. Forms dense mats on water surfaces

  - Habitat: Still or sluggish waters like ponds and ditches

  - Status: Native
